name: Mind Snares: Alice's Journey
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP, Windows Vista, Windows 7, Windows 8 Processor: 1.5 GHz Memory: 512 MB RAM Graphics: 128 MB VRAM DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 1 GB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows XP, Windows Vista, Windows 7, Windows 8 Processor: 2 GHz Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: 256 MB VRAM DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 1 GB available space

reviews.review_text: **  Key was provided by developer for review purposes  **     Mind Snares: Alice's Journey

I love searching things and try puzzles to beat. All that gamers that love this sort of games, too. Buy it and enjoy. The levels changing very, some could come from a fairy tail other are cruel science fiction. Its a look inside the strange minds of this world. A nice quality of details. Sure no master piece but i see something that you not see ;) 8.2 of 10.0 points who love this art of genre.

Overall it was quite ok, but all the puzzles feel a little to familiar, as it's all just recycled from other Artifex Mundi games. The story also fails to gain real traction, it starts out somewhat interesting, but then just paddles along without really advancing much at all. The most frustrating part however is the ending, which there isn't any of, the game just ends without any kind of epilogue or even a proper cliffhanger. This makes the whole experience feel kind of pointless and empty.

This one was decently challenging. It had a good story. Quite interesting. Well done cut scenes. It was a bit creepy at times which added to the fun.   Chapter 2 was my favourite. I really liked the theme. There was a different theme in each chapter which made it more interesting.

The ending was abrupt as quite a few reviewers said. Apart from that a solid HOG with gorgeous graphics, fantastic art design and good sound effects. Solid 3-4 hours of gameplay and you can get all the achievements at one go.
Nice Game good twist and a little deep :D

Excellent point-and-click adventure game. I thought the premise of the story was pretty cool. And the hidden object games were especially well done. Seemed a bit short, but otherwise the overall quality was great. Would love to see a sequel. Thumbs up.

Another HOG from Artifex Mundi with nice graphics and a play style that obviously is geared towards touchscreen play, but works decently well.  Pros: Ok voice acting for what there is, but the third chapter is suspiciously like a middle school haunted house. Beautiful HOG scenes, nice environments Decent story I laughed at the pumpkins.  Cons:  Super short, even for a HOG game. 2 hours and no extra chapters. Nothing really innovative. Same old minigames and puzzle styles.  Decent. Pick it up in a bundle, or don't pay more than 3 or 4 bucks for it by itself.
It's okay, but not great. Due to the high amount of games available, cannot recommend.

Fun game to play to pass the time. The visuals was very beautiful to look at.  When I went to the last chapter I was wondering why I wasn't getting a map. Then when I finished the chapter I was like 'Is that it?' Then I said 'So that's why I didn't get a map!'   The chapter or I should say game ended so abruptly that I was like I wish the game had a proper ending. So keep that in mind if you don't like to play games that pretty much had such an abrupt ending.
Fun, but short puzzler. Great casual game if you enjoy mystery, puzzles and hidden object point and click. Nice varied mix of the aforementioned along with some challenging and fun puzzles.

That was fun, hope there will be more in the series. Fun to leave the real world for more dark places. It did feel however like the 2nd half was rushed compared to the first one. Still recommended for a pleasant little session.
An enjoyable trip through twisted mindscapes inspired by fever dreams while leading the main character on a voyage of self-discovery.

This is my review of Mind Snares: Alice Journey.  I was on ♥♥♥ and found out that they would sell random Steam keys for quite cheap. Me and My Associate thought it would be funny to purchase one and play the game, no matter how bad it looked. This is the product of that experience, and I have to say that We were very pleasantly surprised.  From the outside, this doesn't look like the most appealing game in the world. We thought that it would be kind of naff and a bit dull. The gameplay can be described as straight forward Point and Click Puzzler with Elements of Where's Wally. The art really grows on you and has the same type of charm that you would find in Alice: Madness Returns (It's not only the name that they share in common.)  The plot isn't the strongest point of this game, but it works as the carriage to help understand the setting and gameplay elements. The gaming formula does become quite tiresome towards the end of Alice's Journey, but there is still fun to be had. I would recommend that you give this game a shot at least once, and We shall be trying out some of the creators other games in the future.  Remember Dear Readers, You heard it here first. Off the record, On the QT, and very, Hush-Hush.
if you like hidden object games then this is a very decent one in the casual genre. puzzles aren't too difficult nor are the hidden object scenes too obtuse to find the objects in.
